data.title: Using the Revolut card in Nicaragua | 2024 guide
data.meta_description: Learn about using the Revolut card in Nicaragua. Is it available for visitors to Nicaragua to use? And can residents of Nicaragua get a Revolut card?
data.text:
If you’re planning a trip to Nicaragua - or planning to move there to live, work or study - you’ve got an exciting time ahead. As the Nicaraguan Cordoba (NIO) is the official currency in Nicaragua you’ll need to find convenient ways to spend in NIO while you’re there.

This guide walks through how to use the Revolut card in Nicaragua for convenient and secure transactions, and offers some handy hints about making your money go further when you’re abroad.

Can I use the Revolut card in Nicaragua?

If you are a resident of the USA and have a Revolut card - or if you’re thinking of getting one - you’re probably wondering: can I use my Revolut card to pay for things in Nicaragua?

The answer is yes, you can use the Revolut card for everyday spending in Nicaragua. You can use the card to pay for things in Nicaraguan Cordobas with competitive exchange rates and low transaction fees. This guide walks through how you’ll be able to use your Revolut card to help manage your travel spending.

Unfortunately, the Revolut card is not yet available for residents of Nicaragua. You may find that Wise is a better option for residents; check whether Wise is available below.

See alternatives to Revolut

What happens if I move to Nicaragua?

Revolut does not offer cards in Nicaragua, so your card may stop working. You may still be able to use other services, such as money transfers.

While your ATM card will work in Nicaragua it’s useful to know that cash is still the preferred payment method for many merchants.

You’re unlikely to be able to use your card in smaller stores and restaurants, so carrying cash is essential.

Carrying a low cost ATM card when you’re in Nicaragua is still a smart idea, so you can take out cash when you do find an ATM. You may also be able to use your card in larger hotels or restaurants, particularly in tourist areas.

However, keeping some cash on you at all times, as well as your card or cards is a smart plan, so you’re prepared no matter what happens.

The Nicaraguan Cordoba (NIO) is the official currency in Nicaragua.

You can exchange your USD before you leave the USA if you’d like - but bear in mind that you won’t be able to spend USD in Nicaragua. If you arrive with cash in your pocket you’ll need to exchange it locally, which may come with unexpected costs, and take time out of your trip unnecessarily.

A better plan for lots of people is to get a travel card for spending in NIO while in Nicaragua, with low costs and secure transactions.
